moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d3: I normally play my bishop at this point. 3. Bb5 a6 4. Bxc6 xc6 5. Nxe5 f6 6. Nf3 Bg4 7. O-O is what I usually experience, or something along those lines. I didn't do it here this time.
moves.6. Bd2: I didn't want my pawn structure to be messed up or unbalanced, so I got the other bishop involved.
moves.8. O-O: Defenses are good, but I apply that for both sides.
moves.8... Bg4: He does the same strategy he just did with my other knight.
moves.9... Bxf3 10. Bxf3 Nd4: Knights can be lethal, so I wasn't gonna let that one get in any deeper.
moves.11. Bxd4 exd4: In my opinion, knights are stronger than bishops.
moves.12. c3 dxc3 13. bxc3 O-O: The game is evenly matched so far.
moves.14. Rb1: I hope to gain a pawn.
moves.15. e5: Now I gain an advantage. He could take my pawn, but then his rook would be gone, but not taking the pawn results in losing the knight.
moves.16. exf6 Qxf6: I have a good advantage now.
moves.19. Qd2: ...but my original plan was to let him attack...
moves.19... b5 20. Rxe8+: ...but he was so insistent I did the honors lol
moves.20... Rxe8: But it wasn't the best idea. His b5 pawn is now open for attack.
moves.21... c5 22. dxc5 dxc5 23. Rxc5: My advantage grows further. He doing his best for sure, but he's letting his pawns drop off.
moves.23... Rd8: Of course, removing the pawns allowed him to attack my queen, but we all know I won't let him get it.
moves.24. Bd5 Kh8: A bit surprised he didn't try to defend his a5 pawn.
moves.25. Rxa5: I go another pawn up, my advantage is big! I'm a bit surprised with how he let them go.
moves.26... Qb1+ 27. Kh2: Really a forced move. Moving the queen to protect would of resulted in disaster for me.
moves.27... f6 28. Ra8: Hoping to exchange the last two rooks.
moves.29... Qb8+: I failed to see that coming though.
moves.30. Kh1 Qxa8: My advantage is smaller now, but now I would make it tough for dfb1 by engaging my a and c pawns.
moves.31. c5 Qc6 32. Qc2 Kg8: Not much else he could do.
moves.33. a4 Kf7: Again, not much else he could do.
moves.34. Qc4+: This allowed me though to drive back whatever he was planning.
moves.34... Kg6 35. a5 h5: The f,g, and h pawns on both sides are basically stalemated right now.
moves.36. a6 Kh6 37. a7: Black's lonesome queen can't stop both pawns.
moves.39. c6 Kf7 40. Qa6: This sequence of moves was likely to occur next: 40. Ke7 41. c7 Kd7 42. c8=Q+ Qxc8 43. Qxc8+ Kxc8 44. a8=Q+... I probably would of attacked black's f g and h pawns so I could engage my f g and h pawns so I could get more strong pieces to make checkmate easier. Checkmate is hard to do right now. dfb1 though knew that he would lose his queen and that I would still have a queen and so on. He resigned and this wonderful game was over. I hope you enjoyed this annotation and feel free to comment and rate this annotation.
